text: hi this is Seema and I'm back with a new
lesson on the difference between the
words or prepositions in and on well
recently in one of my videos there was a
huge debate upon the usage of these two
prepositions and I can understand why
there was a confusion because these two
prepositions are very often confused
because we're not very sure as to when
to use it grammatically in the right way
so my topic for today will clear this
confusion once and for all
okay so let's see the first point the
first criteria or the difference between
the two prepositions the first one being
that when you use the word or the
preposition in you are talking about
something in an enclosed space now what
do I mean by an enclosed space okay well
do you see this well this is a box okay
and a box has an enclosed space because
it has physical a physical limitation so
in a box only a certain amount of things
can be contained because it has a
physical limitation and that's what a
enclosed space means okay so let's take
an example which says she is in her room
now I will always use in because I'm
talking about an enclosed space room
your room is enclosed by four walls and
therefore you have a room which is an
enclosed space you can't do anything out
of your room because it has four walls
okay so when I say she is in her room
I'm using the word in because I'm
denoting something in a space which has
a physical boundary but the good thing
about using the preposition in is the
fact that you can also use in if I'm
talking about an enclosed space but a
space which is virtual or a space
enclosed by virtual limitations let's
see how my sentence says I have three
new messages in my inbox we all do a lot
of texting don't we when you have three
messages you don't say I've got three
messages on my inbox you say I have
three messages in my inbox because we're
talking about an inbox being an enclosed
space but not a physical space like a
room or boxes but a virtual space we're
talking about the memory of your inbox
which means that there is only a certain
number of messages that can be contained
in your inbox at one point of time
because it's got a virtual limitation to
it and therefore I will use the
preposition in and not on on the
contrary I will use on when I'm talking
about a surface okay like a surface a
position above or outside an area okay
either a surface or a position above or
outside an area let's see how Charlie
had a tattoo on his arm why do I say on
his arm and not in his arm and arm is a
surface okay so whatever you do on your
arm any kind of art that you do on your
arm is going to be done on the surface
not within your arm
and therefore you will use on the arm
because we're talking about a surface
okay now what about a position above we
talked about they sat on the bench okay
so why do I say on the bench and not in
the bench as I've said a position above
when you sit on the bench you are
sitting in a position above the bench
you don't sit under the bench you sit
above the bench and therefore you say on
the bench however if I would have change
the sentence a little bit I could say
they sat on the bench in the garden
why would I say in the garden and not on
the garden again the garden is a
physical space an enclosed space with
physical limitations so I will always
say they sat on the bench on a position
above the bench in the garden because
we're talking about the garden being an
enclosed space with limitations with
physical limitations well the word in is
used for talking about parts of the day
months your and season well what do I
mean by parts of the day meaning morning
afternoon evening or late at night so if
I'm talking about in as far as a part of
the day is concerned I could say I drink
coffee in the morning I'll use the word
in because I'm talking about the early
part of the day which is the morning I
can talk about in when I'm speaking of
months and yours and seasons too so I
can say her wedding is in July
or her wedding is in October there was a
recession in 2010 I will always use the
word in when I'm specifying a particular
EUR or you could say there was a
recession in 2008 so we're talking about
a year and therefore I will use in
similarly when I talk about seasons
which means you have your summer your
winter your spring the autumn we always
use in my sentence says flowers will
bloom in spring because they do bloom in
spring and when I'm talking about the
season I will always always use in now
let's see when I will use on I will use
on when I'm talking about days which
means Monday to Sunday Monday Tuesday
Wednesday Thursday Friday Saturday
Sunday and dates the third of August the
4th of July and special holidays meaning
Easter Sunday Christmas Eve
New Year's Eve and a lot of other
holidays that all of you celebrate out
there depending on what part of the
world you are in so if I'm talking about
days I can say I'll talk to you on
Friday
you will never say I will call you in
Sunday I will call you on a Sunday or I
go to work on Monday
ok the robbery occurred on January 14th
when you are specifying a particular
date a date not a day but a date you
will always use on so you use on when
you're talking about a day between
Monday to Sunday and you also use on to
specify a particular date now you also
use on for special holidays as I
mentioned so I can say we party hard on
New Year's Eve which we just recently
did didn't we so well
talking about sea about dates days and
special holidays will always have the
word on as opposed to in which talks
about parts of the day months years and
seasons
well the preposition in is also used
with names of cities towns states and
countries okay so when I use the word in
make sure you Club it with the name of a
city a town a state or a country in
these cases you will never use the word
on okay let's see how there are
celebrities in Los Angeles or the
maximum number of celebrities live in
Los Angeles you will never say they live
on Los Angeles because we're talking
about cities we're talking about towns
or States or even maybe a specific
country an example like football is a
big sport in Brazil I will never say on
Brazil because I'm talking about a
country okay and that's when I use the
word in on the contrary I will use the
word on or the preposition on when I'm
talking about a straight name or the
name of a road that I'm living in or
that I happen to know so I will say I
live on peda Road so I'm talking about a
road that I am reciting in that's where
I'm living
okay so I live on pit road I will never
say I live in peda Road or I could say I
live on Elm Street again I use the word
on because I'm talking about a straight
name well that's it for me on this
lesson on the difference between the two
prepositions which are often confused
